title: 109_hr377
content: The Act may be cited as the "Honoring Every Requirement of Exemplary Service Act of 2005" or the "HEROES Act of 2005". Death gratuity enhancements are included in the Act. The "HEROES Act of 2005" includes death gratuity enhancements, increasing the death gratuity to $100,000 for deaths resulting from combat-related causes or causes incurred in designated operations or areas. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases death gratuity amounts for members of the Armed Forces, with additional gratuity payments for deaths before the effective date. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases death gratuity amounts for members of the Armed Forces who died as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred in specific operations or after a certain date. The additional death gratuity amount is $238,000, payable to beneficiaries entitled under section 1477 of title 10, United States Code. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases death gratuity amounts for members of the Armed Forces who died as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred in specific operations or after a certain date. Code to receive payment of the regular military death gratuity in the case of a member's death shall also be entitled to receive the additional death gratuity. The additional death gratuity is defined as the death gratuity provided under paragraph (1), while the regular military death gratuity is a death gratuity payable under sections 1475 through 1477 of title 10, United States Code. The "HEROES Act of 2005" enhances Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases the maximum amount under Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance to $400,000 and provides additional insurance for members serving in certain areas or operations. The "HEROES Act of 2005" increases Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance to $400,000 and offers an additional $150,000 for members who die or are injured in designated combat zones. The additional insurance coverage for members in designated combat zones is $150,000, with a total limit of $400,000. The cost of insurance for $150,000 coverage is covered by contributions and cannot be deducted from the member's pay. The legislation introduces a new paragraph stating that for each month a member is serving in a designated operation or area, the cost of $150,000 insurance coverage will be contributed from the active duty pay appropriation. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to adjust the insurance limit to $400,000. The legislation introduces changes to insurance coverage for members serving in designated operations or areas, including a contribution of $150,000 from active duty pay and an adjustment of the insurance limit to $400,000. Amendments also address requirements for members to reduce or decline insurance, including providing notice to spouses. The legislation introduces changes to insurance coverage for members serving in designated operations or areas, including a contribution of $150,000 from active duty pay and an adjustment of the insurance limit to $400,000. Amendments also address requirements for members to reduce or decline insurance, including providing notice to spouses. Additionally, the amendments specify that a member with a spouse cannot elect not to be insured or to be insured for less than the maximum amount without the written consent of the spouse.
